ï»¿ANNEX 3 Harnessing Innov ition for Financial Inclusion (HiFi) Programme I. The Need & Background Access to services such as borrowi ig, saving or sending money, or secured and affordable payments helps improve the lives of individua s and families, supports the growth of small business, creates jobs, and provides poor people with the neans to withstand shocks and work their way out of poverty. An estimated 2.5 billion adults do not f ave access to formal financial services. 76 percent of the adults in Sub-Saharan Africa and 67 perceni of adults in South Asia do not have access to formal financial services, compared to only 11 percert in high-income countries. In low income countries (LICs), women, on average, are 10 percent less likeli than men to have access to formal financial services while people living in rural areas are nearly 15 per ,ent less likely to have access than their urban counterparts. Technology has the power to bringing the financially excluded masses-especially in the developing world in to the fold of formal financial services as it reduces the costs associated with the small value transactions; reaches out to larger numbers of people with innovative, low cost electronic payment instruments (e.g. mobile phones, pa ment cards, internet e-accounts, etc.) and delivery channels (airtime sellers, grocery shop owners, Poini of Sale systems, the internet, etc.). Technology-enabled delivery channels and business models for f nancial services are broadly described as correspondent/branchless banking because they enable deliver of financial services outside the limited reach of conventional bank branches that overcome the physical infrastructure barrier to access to financial services. However, barring a few highly succ ssful examples, most digital financial services initiatives have failed to deliver large scale results in term, of reaching the un- and under-banked. Notable constraints relate to limited business know-how, including with regard to business model design and market demand, risk aversion, risk capital, misaligned inc -ntives and regulatory landscape. Recognizing that technology has the potential to transform delivery of financial services at the base of the pyramid, the UK Government Depa Iment for International Development (DFID) is supporting financial inclusion through a new programmc called Harnessing Innovation for Financial Inclusion ("HiFi" or the "Programme"). The aim of the Pro ;ramme is to leverage technology and innovative service models to deepen access to formal financial sei vices on a commercial and sustainable basis. II. Objective of the Programme The objective of the Programme is to help expand access to formal financial services to un- and under- banked people, including, but not lii nited, to women and people in fragile and conflict affected areas on a commercially sustainable basis. 1 he Programme will do this by: (i) providing targeted technical assistance to financial service pro -iders to help them develop and scale technology driven business models to deliver financial services to those who currently do not have any or adequate access; (ii) providing knowledge and suppor to regulators and policy makers in developing countries, and international standard setting bodies, to enhance enabling environment for technology-enabled delivery of financial services; and (iii) providing knowledge and expertise to target developing countries in implementing a strategic framework for integrating the modernization of government, retail, and remittance payment systems. 9
ï»¿Harnessing Innovation for Financial Inclusion Programme will be jointly delivered by IFC, the World Bank, including CGAP. HiFi promol es a model of partnership in line with the principles of: ownership, alignment harmonization, managinE for results and mutual accountability. For HiFi, this involves introducing clear accountabilities in I rogramme management, setting targets, assessing effectiveness, and monitoring results. III. Components The Programme will consist )f three (3) components, which will be implemented by the World Bank through the Finance and Marke :s Global Practice including the Consultative Group to Assist the Poor (CGAP), and IFC, through four separate trust funds: 1. Component 1: Knowledge Facility. The objective of the component is to generate and disseminate knowledge and! olutions to develop financial services for the poor. This component will be implemented by th< Work Bank through the Consultative Group to Assist the Poor (CGAP). Activities will inch de: (a) Provision of techni(al assistance, where appropriate jointly with IFC and the World Bank, to support a range of providers (such as mobile network operators, banks and technology provider;) to test and develop innovative financial services solutions for the poor based on a glot al leaming agenda. (b) Provision of expert knowledge and technical assistance, where appropriate jointly with the World Bank, to policy-makers and regulators for enhancing the enabling environment for harnessing of tec inology in delivery of financial services to the poor. (c) Research on needs, preferences, and behaviors of poor people and financial service providers to support the development of innovative solutions. (d) Facilitation of dial gue and coordination between providers and policy-makers to advance innovations. (e) Promotion of peer k arning across industry leaders for branchless banking. It is expected that activities under this component will be carried out in the following countries and may be revised by agreement be ;ween the Donor and CGAP: (i) Bangladesh (ii) Ghana (iii) India (iv) Kenya (v) Myanmar (vi) Pakistan (vii) Tanzania (viii) Uganda (ix) Rwanda. 2. Component 2: Private Sec 'or Advisory Facility. The objective of this component is to provide intensive capacity building ;upport for banks and non-bank businesses in scaling up technology- enabled business models for providing financial services to those who currently do not have adequate or any access to Financial services. This component will be implemented by IFC, in consultation with CGAP a id World Bank where appropriate. Activities under this component will mainly include the following: 10

(b) Scale innovative bus ness models to deliver commercially sustainable financial services to low income clients. (c) Develop and train ag -nt networks. (d) Carry out financial education and marketing campaigns for responsible finance to build the low-income clie its' trust in technology enabled services accelerating uptake and usage. It is expected that activities inder this component will be carried out in the following countries and may be revised by IFC by agreen tent between the Donor and IFC: (i) Afghanistan (ii) Bangladesh (iii) Cote d'Ivoire (iv) Ghana (v) India (vi) Kenya (vii) Myanmar (viii) Nepal (ix) Nigeria (x) Pakistan (xi) Tanzania (xii) Uganda. 3.
